subject: Re: Terminal unstressed -ior & terminal -ion (with y-sound)

messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Paige Gabhart <pgabhart@c...>
wrote:
> I believe that the decay of the "wh" or "hw" sound if you prefer
has
> been taking place for over a century or maybe two. It is not easy
to
> hear the difference in speech unless one happens to be listening
> closely. I believe those whose job it is to do so have mapped
where the
> sound is still used in the U.S. and where it isn't. My
understanding is
> that approximately 20% of the population still uses the sound. I
> suspect younger speakers may be more likely to ignore the sound.
>
> For those who have never used it, it seems superfluous as you
indicate.
> However, for those of us who do use it, deleting it from QS, would
make
> the alphabet less accurate in its transcription of our speech. We
would
> resent that as much as anyone else would if someone suggested the
> deletion of a phoneme which they happen to be fond of because it
appears
> in their idiolect. For example, if we decided that English should
no
> longer use the "awe" sound, this would annoy many people across
the
> country. Nevertheless, I believe Canadians are quite content to
avoid
> its use altogether. An example: "cot" and "caught" are pronounced
the
> same. Sure seems peculiar to me, but it doesn't keep me from
> understanding them.
>
>I counsel not throwing symbols out just because you don't happen to
>use that particular sound. Somewhere, there are others who do.

I would counter with the following two points:

1) Read himself advocated spelling homogeny regardless of
pronunciation. I cite his unification of several similar sounds into
#36 as one example. A simliar example is that all r's are to be
spelled even though they aren't pronounced. Further, almost all
words are spelled precisely the same between UK English and American
English, the differences in pronunciation arising almost entirely
from the colloquial differences in vowel pronunciation. Considering
as vowel sounds are modified colloquially by the consonants that
surround them, would it not make sense to join similar sounds into
one (or two) letters and simply let the consonants define them? That
is almost entirely the way it is done now.

The only reason I have any beef with this at all is because QS was
designed to speed up and make more efficient reading and writing. If
we all write based entirely upon our accents, then words that were
formerly rendered identically in T.O. will be different in QS. This
seems like a step backwards to me.
